NAEB Radio Network
The program exchange which later developed into the NAEB Radio
Network began in 1949 with operation of what came to be known as the
“bicycle network,** Station vVNYC, New York, made five sets of recordings
of the 1949 Herald Tribune Forum which were distributed to and aired by
22 NAEB member stations, who "bicycled" them from one to the other.
By 1950 the "bicycle network9* had advanced to the point where several
stations agreed to exchange programs by tape recording. (It will be re¬
called that, although the organization had existed since 1925, there was
no permanent NAEB Headquarters at this time,) Several programs were
recorded in the New York area by WNYC for distribution and the Associa¬
tion received a gift of tape from the Cooper Union for use in the project.
By May it could be reported that the "network, which is enjoying tremen¬
dous growth, will soon be able to furnish four hours of programs per week
to member stations, and will include selected programs from the BBC and
